Conclusion


Social interaction via smartphone can benefit sleep quality
Interaction with close contacts prolong sleep
Interaction with certain relationships of contacts (e.g. family) prolong sleep

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text: Social Network Activation

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Hypothesis 1






H1: Activating social networks with a higher Degree Centrality score reduces the time spent on a smartphone.

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Hypothesis 2






H2: Activating social networks with a higher K-Core score reduces the time spent on a smartphone.

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Hypothesis 3

H3 (1): An increase in communication with contacts with high degree centrality improves the effectiveness of degree centrality in reducing smartphone usage.   
H3 (2): An increase in communication with contacts with high K-Core improves the effectiveness of K-Core in reducing smartphone usage.

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Conclusion


Degree Centrality does not affect non-communication smartphone use but improves overall smartphone use by increasing the time spent on communication. H1 is not supported.
K-Core reduces overall smartphone use( Communication, others and overall).  H2 is supported.
Communication frequency shows NO moderating impact on the effectiveness of network features.  H3 is not supported.
Network features outperform traditional constructs (Trust, Social Distance (Closeness)).

text:
Result 3
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Result 3: Addiction
global id egoid
global t date2
global ylist addic_noncom90
global mainIV  active_nodes out_contacts  num_edges  steps minsasleep trust close position duration
global Social_Control degree_centrality core_number
global Other_Control i.insession i.weekday community naps nap_minsasleep
global fe i.studyweek
*Set data as panel data
sort $id $t
xtset $id $t

xtreg $ylist $fe  $Other_Control $Social_Control  $mainIV , fe cluster($id) 
xtlogit $ylist $fe  $Other_Control $Social_Control  $mainIV , fe cluster($id) or
outreg2 using SoUnAcSl.tex, append dec(3) addtext(Communication, Full, Unit F.E., YES, Week F.E, YES) keep($mainIV $Social_Control)  title("90 Addiction Estimation")

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Result 3: Addiction Esimation (Logistic)

Addiction is defined as:

Overall addiction: overall screen time > 300 min
Non-communication-drive addiction: Non-communication screen time > 240 min
Communication-drive addiction: Communication screen time > 40 min

global id egoid
global t date2
global ylist addic_noncom90
global mainIV  active_nodes out_contacts  num_edges  steps minsasleep trust close position duration
global Social_Control degree_centrality core_number
global Other_Control i.insession i.weekday community naps nap_minsasleep
global fe i.studyweek
*Set data as panel data
sort $id $t
xtset $id $t

xtreg $ylist $fe  $Other_Control $Social_Control  $mainIV , fe cluster($id) 
xtlogit $ylist $fe  $Other_Control $Social_Control  $mainIV , fe cluster($id) or
outreg2 using SoUnAcSl.tex, append dec(3) addtext(Communication, Full, Unit F.E., YES, Week F.E, YES) keep($mainIV $Social_Control)  title("90 Addiction Estimation")

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Specification 1


\(\begin{equation} \begin{split} \text{Screen Time}_{it} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Social Network Features}_{it} + \alpha \cdot X_{it} + \theta_i + \lambda_t + \varepsilon_{it} \end{split} \label{e1}\end{equation}\)


\(\text{Screen Time}_{it}\): Smartphone use time before users fall asleep
\(\text{Social Network Features}_{it}\): Degree Centrality and K-Core
\(\text{X}_{it}\): Control variables: Steps, sleep duration, naps, etc.
\(\theta_i\): Individual fixed effect (students)
\(\lambda_t\): Time fixed effect (day)

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Specification 2
\(\begin{equation} \begin{split} \ln \left(\frac{\operatorname{Pr}\left(\text { Addiction }_{it}=1 \mid \boldsymbol{X}_{i t}\right)}{1-\operatorname{Pr}\left(\text { Addiction }_{it}=1 \mid \boldsymbol{X}_{i t}\right)}\right) = \beta_{0}+ \beta_{1} \cdot \text{Social Network Features}_{it}+ \\ \alpha \cdot X_{it}+\theta_{i} +\lambda_{t}+\varepsilon_{it} \end{split} \label{e2} \end{equation}\)


\(\text{Screen Time}_{it}\): Smartphone use time before users fall asleep
\(\text{Social Network Features}_{it}\): Degree Centrality and K-Core
\(\text{X}_{it}\): Control variables: Steps, sleep duration, naps, etc.
\(\theta_i\): Individual fixed effect (students)
\(\lambda_t\): Time fixed effect (day)

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text: Result 1 & 2 (Centrality & K-Core):

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Research Question
Humans are inherently social beings.

Social engagement ➟ belongingness, social fulfillment, etc (Luo et al. 2020).
Social isolation ➟ anxiety, depression (Robb et al. 2020), and suicide (Garnett F. & Curtin C. 2023).



Research Gap

Prior research heavily focus on social interaction volume
Structure of Social network ➟ human behavior?



Context:
Social isolation ➟ Smartphone Addiction

title: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text: Methodology

title: SP2 Reveiw Response: Social Network Activation: Application in Smartphone Use
text:
Dr.Idris AdjeridDr.Jiayi Liu





Thank you for your valuable comments and feedback.

Review Response for Dr.Jiayi Liu







No.
Comments
Responses




1
It appears to be that those with higher core-number are mostly close friends. Then one could say that the story is actually much simpler: merely engaging with close friends is what matters. Can you argue for using network features, like core-number, against more intuitive metrics such as contact closeness in this context?
Thank you for your constructive comments. We measured the social distance of smartphone users with their contacts, as well as their level of trust in those contacts, which are the common measurement of interpersonal relationships.
The estimation of the above two constructs suggest that they do not have significant impact on participants smartphone use behavior. Please refer to Table 5:



2
A fundamental assumption is that social interactions mainly occur through calls and messages. Although the author has presented data showing a link between self-reported interaction levels and observed call/message frequencies, this doesn’t establish that calls/messages are the primary channels of interaction. People could have spent more time on other social platforms and offline activities (with the time spent also aligning with the self-reported interaction levels). How do you plan to address these potential unobserved interactions? Or can you justify they don’t affect your results?
This is an important issue that we need to address. Thanks for pointing this out. First, for the unobserved offline social interactions, there could be two categories:

Smartphone users’ offline social interactions were initiated by online communication and then it was siwthed to offline social interaction. In this situation , the activation of social network is activated by smartphone communication. This scenario could support our 1 & and 2 hypothesis: activating embedded contacts and interacting with them could facilitate offline social engagement.
Offline social interaction is independent of smartphone communication. In another word, the activation of social network is not based on smartphone communication.
We identified smartphone users who are addicted to smartphone, which are those who spent excessive time on smartphone.

Second, in terms of social interactions happening on other platforms, it is indeed unobservable in our data set. However, based on the market share of the most popular mobile messaging channels, our data covered the leading four channels (Whatsapp, Phone calls, Facebook messager and Texting (SMS):
Therefore, we suppose that our data has covered the majority of mobile communication channels.


3

title: Behavior Segmentation for Smartphone Use
text: We cluster the smartphone use behaviors based on the three major metrics of smartphone use actions: Screen time, unlock frequency and message.
